titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Photographs, 1914-present CTC.1966.03
titlestmt.author: William Daw.

did.unittitle: Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Photographs
did.abstract: Within the Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Photographs are over one thousand images related to the history of the performing arts in Pittsburgh. They include images of Pittsburgh theatre venues and local arts groups' production photos.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection, 1901-2002, AIS.1971.05, Archives & Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh Library System
Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Performing Arts Photographs (finding aid in-progress)

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection has amassed a large collection of photographs related to the performing arts. Within that collection are over one thousand photos and other types of images related to Pittsburgh. The majority of these photographs were acquired through numerous donations from members of the press or the local performing arts groups themselves. They include images of Pittsburgh theatre venues and local arts groups' production photos.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Reba Sell and William Daw in 2014.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Donations are occasionally added to the collection. These donations come from the producing groups themselves or members of the press. If you are interested in donating photographs to the collection, please contact the Special Collections Department staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh performing arts photographs are interfiled within the Curtis Collection's larger preforming arts photograph collection. For the most part the collection consists of 8 x 10" or 5 by 7" photographic prints, however, there is also a small amount of negatives, slides, digital images, etc. All of the photographs are arranged in one large alphabetical system. This finding aid was written and the photos were categorized into three series (People, Productions, and Theatres) to facilitate researcher browsing.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Photographs, 1907-present, CTC.1966.03, Curtis Theatre Collection, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Photographs, 1907-present, CTC.1966.03, Curtis Theatre Collection, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into three series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Contained in this series are images from theatre productions by Pittsburgh-related performing arts groups. Each item contains a scope note that details the individuals in the photograph, who produced the production, and when and where the production took place. Please note that this series does not contain images from touring productions that were produced in Pittsburgh. Images from touring productions can be found in the Touring series within the Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Performing Arts Photographs. The majority of the photos date from the early 1970s through the early 2000s. The series is arranged alphabetically by the production title. When there are multiple productions of the same play, the producing group is identified in the title and the scope note.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains images of Theatre buildings. Many of the photos are from the City Photographer's Collection. For the most part they are exterior shots. The series is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Located on Liberty Avenue near Wood Street. Photocopy of photograph from the Carnegie Library's Pennsylvania Room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Aldine Theatre was located at the corner of Liberty Avenue and Oak Alley. It was also known as the Victoria, the Senator, and from 1950-1976 the New Nixon Theatre. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Alvin Theatre was located at 115 Sixth Street. It opened in 1891 and was also known as the Shubert-Alvin, the New Harris-Alvin, the Senator J.P. Harris, and finally the Gateway Theater. Ten of the photographs are negatives reproduced from the Merriman Scrapbook collection. Please note that those originals are from 1908, but these negatives were created in the 1990s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Auburn Theatre was located on Baum Boulevard. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Enright Theatre was located in East Liberty on Penn Avenue. The Enright opened in 1928. These photographs show street views from the Enright. One photograph shows the Enright marquee. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Originally built in 1903 as the Gayety Theater, the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust purchased this 1300-seat venue, then called the Fulton Theater, in 1988. The Trust renovated and reopened the Fulton in 1991. The theater was renamed the Byham Theater in 1995, in recognition of a gift from William C. and Carolyn M. Byham. These photographs are of the Fulton Theater from Sixth Street. These photographs are from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Gayety Theatre was originally built in 1903. Other names of this theatre include the Fulton and the Byham. These photographs are images of the Gayety Theatre on Penn Avenue from Duquesne Way. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains photographic negatives of advertisements and programs related to the Grand Opera House. Unfortunately, we do not have any photos of the Grand Opera House structure. Included in the file are images of a Chimes of Normandy broadside from March 4, 1878, the front cover of a Grand Opera House program from August 27, 1906, and a February 1, 1925 Pittsburgh Post advertisement for the Dark Swan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Grand Theatre was a motion picture theatre located at 1851 Centre Avenue. Part of the Irene Kaufman Settlement House can be seen in the photo. This image is from the City Photographer's Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are from Federal and Erie Streets. The Kenyon Theatre was built in 1909 and remained in ownership by the Kenyon family until 1919. The theatre remained standing until it was demolished for the raising of Allegheny Center. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is a street view of the Liberty Theatre on Liberty Avenue. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Liberty Theatre was located at 1200 East Carson Street in the Southside. Photographs show the Michaels brothers (owners) and family, the exterior of the theatre, and unidentified shows performed there. Collection also includes original negatives of the photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is from 6th Street and Fort Duquesne Boulevard looking South. Photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is from Penn Avenue from Barkers Way. Photograph is part of the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of the Miles Theatre on Penn Avenue. Photograph is taken on the north side of the street looking west at Sandusky Street. Photograph is part of the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The New Leona Theatre was opened in 1927 as the Stahl Million Dollar Theatre. The New Leona Theatre was located in the Homestead section of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The original Nickelodeon was built in June 1905 by John Paul Harris. The Pittsburgh Nickelodeon was located on Smithfield Street. Please note that this is a photograph of an artist's rendering of the entrance to the theatre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Nixon Theatre was opened in 1903 on the corner of Sixth Avenue and William Penn Place. The Nixon was the main theatre in Pittsburgh for Broadway touring productions. The final performance at the Nixon was in 1950. Photographs show the Nixon Theatre with marquees for Brigadoon, Oklahoma!, and the final performance at the Nixon, Diamond Lil, featuring Mae West.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of the Oakland Theatre at 205 Atwood Street looking east from the opposite side of the street. This photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are of the Pittsburgh Playhouse from the corner of Craft Avenue and Hamlet Street in Oakland. The Pittsburgh Playhouse began as a community theatre in 1934. The theatre was purchased by Point Park College in 1973 and has served as the venue for their performing arts productions through the present day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are of the Pittsburgh Theatre on Fifth Avenue. The Pittsburgh Theatre was built in 1833 and later became known as the Old Drury Theater. The Old Drury was torn down in 1870.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of the Plaza Theater on Liberty Avenue. Photograph is part of the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are street views of the Roosevelt Theatre. Two photographs are on Center Avenue in front of the Irene Kaufman Settlement House. The third photograph is on the corner of Green and Linton Streets, looking South. The Roosevelt Theatre was a motion picture theatre located in the Hill District of Pittsburgh. These photographs are from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is a view of Schenley Theatre from Forbes Street, looking East. Photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is taken looking East from a rooftop along Penn Avenue. The Sheridan Square Theatre was a Vaudeville Picture theatre. Photograph is from the Pittsburgh City Photographer's Collection. Collection also includes the photograph's negative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Sherwood Forest Theatre was a community theatre in Murrysville, Pennsylvania. It operated from 1950 through 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Stanley Theatre was located on Penn avenue at Seventh avenue in downtown Pittsburgh. The theatre was renovated and renamed the Benedum Center of the Performing Arts in 1987. There are a series of seven photographs documenting the construction of the Stanley from early November 1926 through the end of April 1927. Appearing on five of the seven photos is the following - "Theatre and Clark office building for Stanley - Rowland - Clark Corp. Hoffman Henon Co. architects & contractors." These photos appear to have been printed in the 1970s or 1980s. Each photo roughly measures 40' x 24' and there are three copies of each photograph.
These photographs are filed separately from the rest of the Curtis photographs due to their size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Syria Mosque was located on Bigelow Boulevard in Oakland. The building was unveiled in 1919 and demolished in 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Third Street Theatre was located on Third Avenue. This was Pittsburgh's first theatre and was in operation from 1817-1820. This is a photograph of an artist's rendering of that theatre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series is primarily for photos of the entire company of a local Pittsburgh theatre group or similar types of photographs. There are also a few photographs documenting early theatre advertising. The series is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Absolute Pitts was a Pittsburgh comedy troupe. Appearing in these photos are troupe members Hugh McGough, Rosa Copeland Miller, Kathleen Davies, Elinor Nathanson, and Joe Kennedy. Photos by Harvey Nathanson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This folder contains two images of the Comedy Improv troupe, the Amish Monkeys.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This photograph shows several members of the Fine Line Theatre Company from the 1978/1979 season. Appearing in the photo are Bonnie Gilmore, Robert Koch, Rick Dolnack, Fred Donatelli, and John Waterson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of Gargaro's Good Vibrations 1996 group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of Gargaro's Good Vibrations 1997 group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of Gargaro's Stars of Tomorrow 1997 group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Herman Hartman was the manager of the Herman Hartman Dinner Theatre and the Mellwood Playhouse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are of the Irene Kaufmann Settlement Players. The 1937 image is the cast of Nine Pine Street, dated October 27, 1937. The 1938 image is the cast of Night of January 16th, dated February 16-17, 1938.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These photographs document a library exhibit on the career of journalist Kaspar Monahan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Appearing in two photographs are Gillian Strain, Trisha Stahl and Katie McCreary. The three actresses were a part of the Little Grovers Theatre Company. The performances were held on Indiana University of Pennsylvania's campus and included cast and staff members from Indiana University of Pennsylvania's theatre department.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are advertisements for performances at various theatres in Pittsburgh. Some theatres included are the Gayety, Pitt, Fulton, Variety, and Academy. The majority of the advertisements are for minstrel and vaudeville shows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains one unidentified slide from the 1993-1994 season from the Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre. The photograph was taken by David Farmerie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph is of the cover of the September 15th, 1900 issue of Pittsburg Bulletin. The cover shows images of the Harry Williams's Academy, Grand Opera House, Duquesne, Bijou, and Alvin theatres.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains two photographs which depict graphics that were used in advertising the Pittsburgh International Children's Theater's 1998-1999 Family Series. Images are included for The Three Little Pigs, Al Simmons in Celery Stalks at Midnight, Laura Ingalls Wilder: Growing Up on the Prairie, Landis & Co. Theatre of Magic's Beauty and the Beast, and Circo Zoppe' Europa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains a CD-R disc with 23 images from the 17th annual Pittsburgh New Works Festival. The Festival was August 19th through September 30th, 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This glass lantern slide advertises the first annual Pittsburgh Screen Club ball. The reception and dance was held at the Motor Square Garden on February 14th, 1916. Images of Belle Gold, Etta Pillard, Mazie Fogarty, Marion Ballou, and Harry Stubbs appear on the slide and were advertised to appear at the event which benefited the Actor's Fund of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains a publicity photo for the Robert Morris Colonial Theater's 10th anniversary season. Appearing in the photo with a cake are Alan Peter Byrne, Victoria Falco, Thomas V. Gaydos, Leslie L. Birtig, and Jim Sharp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph includes Pat Kording, Herb Schacter, Ron Grusofsky, and Jeannie Coffy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photographs are advertisements for performances at various theatres in Pittsburgh. One photograph is from October 1914, advertising shows such as: Moulin Rouge Girls, Gay Morning Glories, and The Round Up. The second photograph is from September 1926, advertising shows such as: Ben Hur, Wine Woman and Song, and Kandy Kid. Some theatres included are the Gayety, Pitt, Fulton, Variety, and Academy. Photographs are from the Pittsburgh City Photographer's Collection.
